justifications: the situation now is in a whole different category.
The UK vote to leave the EU will damage Europe.

target.topic: damage to US interests in Europe

justifications: The UK vote to leave the EU will damage US interests in Europe for many years to come.
The self-inflicted political uncertainty will make the UK a considerably less able partner to deal with the genuine pressing issues of the day.
Weak and inexperienced new leaders will be preoccupied with developing a form of 'no-fault insurance' with the EU to mitigate the downside of leaving.
David Cameron, who will long be remembered as the author of an ill-conceived referendum designed only for electoral advantage
His Conservative Party colleagues quickly transformed the leadership competition into a sordid little soap opera.
the clever/devious Michael Gove somehow prompting the clever, reduced, and frightened Brexit supporter Boris Johnson into heading for the hills himself
The continuously feckless Labour Party grew even less impressive as Labour Members of Parliament indicated no confidence in their leader, Jeremy Corbyn.
Corbyn seems intent on bringing former British Prime Minister Tony Blair to justice over his decision to enter the Iraq war.

the first reaction of Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon following the Brexit vote was a quick trip to Brussels to assure EU leaders that the Scots wanted nothing to do with what was an essentially English decision.

Nicola Sturgeon... to assure EU leaders that the Scots wanted nothing to do with what was an essentially English decision, and to note that the Scots had indicated the same by an overwhelming vote to remain in the EU.
Even Queen Elizabeth II felt the need to recommend that UK politicos allow 'sufficient room for quiet thinking and contemplation.'

It was delicious accidental irony that she delivered these words at the opening of Scotland's Parliament, where the first reaction of Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon following the Brexit vote was a quick trip to Brussels to assure EU leaders that the Scots wanted nothing to do with what was an essentially English decision.
